column1: Gahanna ( gə-HAN-ə) is a city situated in northeast Franklin County
column3: United States. It is a suburb of Columbus. The population was 33
column4: 248 at the 2010 census. It was founded in 1849.

column1: Gahanna was founded along the Big Walnut Creek in 1849 by John Clark of Ross County from 800 acres (320 ha) of land that his father
column3: had purchased from Governor Worthington in 1814. Clark named his property the Gahanna Plantation
column4: from which the City of Gahanna derives its name. The name Gahanna is derived from a Native American word for three creeks joining into one and is the former name of the Big Walnut Creek. The City of Gahanna's Official Seal refers to this confluence of three creeks with the inscription "Three In One".

column1: Gahanna maintained a considerable rivalry with the adjacent village of Bridgeport. Located directly across Granville Street from Gahanna and also along the banks of the Big Walnut Creek
column2: Bridgeport was founded in 1853 by Jesse Baughman
column3: a former Franklin County Commissioner. The two villages eventually put aside their differences and merged into one. They adopted the name Gahanna as there was already another village in Ohio called Bridgeport. In March 1881
column4: 55 citizens of Gahanna petitioned Franklin County to incorporate the village. The incorporation was granted in June and was recorded on August 8
column5: 1881. The now-incorporated village then held its first mayoral election and on October 6
column10: United Express Flight 6291 crashed in Gahanna
column11: killing five of the eight people on board.

column1: The city of Gahanna is in the Gahanna-Jefferson Public School District. The school colors are blue and gold. Gahanna has seven elementary schools
column3: and only one high school: Lincoln High School. However
column4: there are also several private education options
column9: as well as various parochial schools.

column2: Gahanna has worked hard at revitalizing the downtown "Olde Gahanna" section of the city. In October 2004
column3: Gahanna's new Creekside Gahanna redevelopment and park extension project began
column4: making way for everything from public spaces and restaurants to residences and office space. As of late 2007
column5: the project businesses began to open. The area includes a 389-space public parking garage. The multimillion-dollar project is expected to bring in up to 150 new residents as well as bolster tourism to the area.Gahanna also has an aggressive brownfields assessment and redevelopment program that includes the development of a community-wide brownfields inventory
column6: the cleanup of a major abandoned landfill
column7: and city-initiated assessments and demolition of abandoned or environmentally suspect properties.

column1: The largest brownfields redevelopment project to date is the closure of the Bedford I Landfill
column2: completed in late 2007. The closure was a result of a 2005 public-private development partnership with private firm Value Recovery Group
column5: and non-profit Central Ohio Community Improvement Corporation to remediate and redevelop the abandoned Bedford I Landfill. The 200-acre (0.81 km2) site was transformed into Central Park of Gahanna
column6: a major greenfield development campus that features a golf academy known as The Golf Depot. The City of Gahanna and Value Recovery Group
column7: which owns nearly 60 acres of the developable land
column8: have been working to attract recreational
column10: and office development and continue to solicit development opportunities. Funding for this major project included $3
column12: 000 from the Clean Ohio Redevelopment Fund
column16: 000 from the Community Development Block Grant program
column20: and other investments by the Central Ohio CIC.

column1: Gahanna was listed as #96 of the Top 100 Best Places to Live in 2007 by Money magazine.Among the companies based in Gahanna is the utility company AEP Ohio.
